statement.text: Tibial artery exposure is essential for limb salvage bypass in patients with critical limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI). The three tibial vessels - anterior tibial (AT), posterior tibial (PT), and peroneal arteries - each require specific surgical approaches. Selection of target vessel depends on angiographic patency, quality, and runoff to the foot. Tibial exposure represents advanced vascular surgical technique requiring precise anatomic knowledge.
statement.formal: Tibial Exposure: AT (lateral calf, between tibia and fibula, through interosseous membrane) | PT (medial calf, behind soleus, at ankle behind malleolus) | Peroneal (lateral calf, fibula resection or medial approach) | Critical: Small vessels (2-3mm), paired venae comitantes, associated nerves

explanation.intuition: The tibial vessels are like three smaller roads branching off from the popliteal artery highway, each running to different parts of the foot and ankle. The anterior tibial runs down the front of the leg (becoming the dorsalis pedis at the ankle), the posterior tibial runs behind the inner ankle bone (you can feel this pulse at your ankle), and the peroneal runs between the two bones of the calf (hardest to access).
explanation.key_insight: For limb salvage, you only need ONE good tibial vessel with continuous flow to the foot. The choice of which vessel to target depends on which one is open all the way down - a patent posterior tibial at the ankle is useless if there's a long occlusion proximally. Preoperative imaging (angiography or CTA) is essential for planning which vessel to expose.
explanation.technical_details: Anterior Tibial: (1) Lateral leg incision between tibia and fibula; (2) Incise crural fascia; (3) Separate anterior tibial muscle from extensor digitorum longus; (4) Artery lies on interosseous membrane with deep peroneal nerve; (5) Paired venae comitantes flank artery. Posterior Tibial: (1) Medial leg incision posterior to tibia; (2) Divide soleus from tibia; (3) Artery lies with tibial nerve and venae comitantes; (4) At ankle, artery is behind medial malleolus. Peroneal: (1) Lateral approach with fibula resection for direct exposure; (2) Or medial approach through below-knee popliteal dissection, tracing tibioperoneal trunk; (3) Artery lies deep, close to fibula; (4) Most challenging tibial exposure.
common_misconceptions: All tibial vessels are equally easy to access - the peroneal is significantly more challenging
Tibial bypass has poor outcomes - with good technique and appropriate selection, 5-year patency is 60-70%
If one tibial is occluded, limb is unsalvageable - only one patent vessel is needed
Tibial arteries are too small for bypass - 2-3mm vessels can be anastomosed with proper technique

definitions_glossary.anterior_tibial_artery: Tibial vessel running in the anterior compartment, becomes dorsalis pedis
definitions_glossary.posterior_tibial_artery: Tibial vessel behind medial malleolus, supplies plantar foot
definitions_glossary.peroneal_artery: Tibial vessel along fibula, often spared in diabetic disease
definitions_glossary.tibioperoneal_trunk: Short segment giving origin to posterior tibial and peroneal arteries
definitions_glossary.venae_comitantes: Paired veins running alongside arterial conduit

indications: Tibial bypass for critical limb-threatening ischemia
Pedal bypass origin (distal posterior tibial or dorsalis pedis)
contraindications: No patent tibial target vessel to foot (consider primary amputation)
Non-ambulatory patient with limited life expectancy (relative)

anterior_tibial_exposure.incision: Lateral leg, between tibia and fibula
anterior_tibial_exposure.muscles: Between tibialis anterior and extensor digitorum longus
anterior_tibial_exposure.artery_location: On interosseous membrane, paired venae comitantes

levels.at_ankle: Becomes dorsalis pedis on dorsum of foot

posterior_tibial_exposure.incision: Medial leg, 1cm posterior to tibial edge
posterior_tibial_exposure.artery_location: Deep with tibial nerve and venae comitantes

levels.proximal: At tibioperoneal trunk, below BK popliteal
levels.mid_leg: Behind soleus, adequate for most bypasses
levels.at_ankle: Behind medial malleolus, under flexor retinaculum

peroneal_exposure.lateral_approach: Fibula resection provides direct access (most invasive)
peroneal_exposure.medial_approach: Through BK popliteal exposure, trace tibioperoneal trunk
peroneal_exposure.notes: Often patent when PT and AT are diseased (diabetic pattern)

complications.prevention: Identify nerve lateral to artery, protect during dissection
complications.management: Foot drop if injured, usually recovers over months

complications.prevention: Nerve is behind artery at ankle, identify early
complications.management: Sensory loss to plantar foot, motor loss rare

complications.prevention: Paired veins flank artery, separate carefully
complications.management: Ligate or clip, usually not significant

complications.prevention: Atraumatic technique, avoid tension on closure

definition.@value: Surgical exposure of the anterior tibial, posterior tibial, or peroneal arteries for limb salvage bypass or other vascular procedures

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Tibial and Pedal Arterial Exposure.
Conte MS, et al. Global vascular guidelines on the management of CLTI. J Vasc Surg. 2019;69(6S):123S-291S.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy of each tibial vessel and its surgical approach
Select the appropriate tibial target based on angiographic findings
Perform exposure of the anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and peroneal arteries
Identify and protect adjacent nerves during tibial exposure
clinical_pearls: The peroneal artery is often patent when AT and PT are diseased in diabetics - the 'peroneal-sparing' pattern
At the ankle, the PT is behind the medial malleolus - you can palpate the pulse there
The AT becomes the dorsalis pedis on top of the foot - a natural extension of exposure
Tibial arteries are 2-3mm diameter - use appropriate magnification and fine sutures (7-0)
Venae comitantes are paired veins that flank each artery - separate them for exposure

medicalCode.description: Inspection of anterior tibial artery, open approach
